Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: In this course, I learned about the South Asian diaspora in the United States. I learned how to use the tools of cultural studies and visual analysis by engaging with television series, ethnographies, theoretical pieces and pop culture articles. The multidisciplinary aspect of the class was rich in that it allowed us to think about the South Asian diaspora from a variety of angles and from a myriad of perspectives.

I have learnt more about the South Asian diaspora in the American context, something that is entirely new to me. I have also gotten to gain knowledge about the historical events that has reshaped the South Asian Americans' identity.
I developed the ability to critically evaluate my own subject-position as part of the South Asian American diaspora.
The limitations of aspiring to be a model minority.
This class helped me become more comfortable using academic terms to talk about race and identity and understanding cultural critics theories.
I gained theoretical frameworks through which to become a more critical consumer of popular culture as well as to understand the making of the South Asian diaspora within the North American context.

I learned more information about the South Asian American narrative and how diasporic formation works. I gained valuable insights on how gender roles are influenced by migratory patterns and how that shapes our story.
Material was at times very theoretical and hard to understand for someone with little background

This course has excellent, interesting and varied readings. I looked forward to the material Professor Grewal would assign us every week. The seminar itself was also fun and engaging. Even though we had a full class, there were a variety of voices and people were endlessly enthusiastic. The best part of the course was the diversity of readings and methodologies we used. It truly made it seem like there was something for everyone.

The strength lies in the readings which goes in depth about the perennial struggle to realising one's identity. Another strength lies in how Prof Grewal makes it a point to always begin the class by asking each and everyone of us for our insights about the readings.
Kind of a pity party at times, far too focused on the post-modern post-structuralist understandings of race and diaspora. Not too committed to actual ideological challenges to hegemony.
Great selection of readings and class discussion. Fewer themes and more weeks on them would be nice -- this could be a year sequence easily!

Since the class is only once a week, we dont get to cover enough material and its difficult to focus for two hours in the evening. However, the readings we did discuss and topics we went over were engaging and eye-opening.

Beginning of class felt a bit slow with a lot of interesting pop culture discussions that I think could have been enriched with some more theoretical readings/discussions that came later in the course.

The discussion was generative and very engaging and the readings on the syllabus built on each other and interacted together well. The papers each gave a chance to think more critically using the thinkers we talked about in class.

The high point of the course is a creative final project that allows you to explore an aspect in the course through a creative lens. I would not recommend this class to someone who hasn't taken any classes on race/gender/culture - I think its important to have this background to get more out of the course. It may also be harder to write good essays without this theoretical background.

I would recommend this course to any student at Yale. Whether you are intimately familiar with the South Asian diaspora or not, there are important insights to be gained from both the content and methods in this class.

I will definitely recommend this course as it presents to us important aspects on the diaspora in the most enriching and exciting way as possible. Given the interactive structure which even gave us the opportunity to plan the lessons for one of our classes this course is indeed of a unique approach.
Only if you are interested in a very particular way of approaching a very particularized subject.

Yes! This class was amazing. I learned so much, got to think critically about my identity, had the freedom to shape class discussion and learn from my peers, and Prof. Grewal is both lovely and a genius. Thank you for a class on South Asian Americans!
Absolutely, especially for those from South Asia.
Yes! Its a lot of reading and you have to be able to pace yourself, but the discussions and realizations are well worth it.
Yes, very interesting discussions and the class environment was great.

I would recommend this class! Professor Grewal is a top-notch professor and the class really helped me to become a more critical consumer of popular culture as well as to understand further the context of the South Asian diaspora within North America.
Yes, it was very valuable in helping me understand how race and gender affect identity and would thus help many others gain similar valuable knowledge
